title: Caregiver Psychoeducation and Support: Improving Outcomes in AD/ADRD
description_brief: This study is piloting an internet-based intervention to provide support for caregivers of VA patients with Alzheimer's disease or related memory difficulties (ADRD). Veterans with a clinical diagnosis of ADRD and their caregiver/relatives will be randomized to receive one of two interventions: (1) customary care (cc) and access to an intensive, interactive online education and support website intervention for 6 months, or (2) cc and monthly brief telephone calls with project staff for six month. It is hypothesized that participation in the intensive intervention will result in a reductions in patient problematic behavior and caregiver responses to it, reduced caregiver burden and depression, and improved medication adherence at the end of treatment, and more patients remaining at home through the 12 months post-randomization period..
description_detailed:
Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a progressive brain disease resulting in cognitive and functional decline. While some pharmacological agents and behavioral programs are now available to slow the rate of decline, there is no cure. Caregivers, who typically are the female spouses or daughters of afflicted individuals, must confront both the deterioration of a loved one, and that person's need for increasingly demanding care. Caregivers tend to experience high levels of depression, anxiety, and burden. Data suggest that providing education, social support, and ongoing professional consultation to families involved in the care of a relative with AD results in improvement in caregiver psychological status, and sometimes even slows the functional decline of the patient.

Recent technological advancements in video conferencing, online communication, and streaming audio/video presentations, which are increasingly easy to use and gaining widespread acceptance among mental health professionals as well as the public, have given rise to a great deal of interest in telemedicine and telepsychiatry. This study tested an Internet-based family intervention for AD that relatives can access from their homes with ease, and at no cost. In addition to improving patient outcomes through instruction of effective behavioral management, we proposed that participation in an Internet program would also reduce caregiver depression and burden. Fifty-three veterans with a clinical diagnosis of AD and their caregiver/relatives were randomized to receive one of two interventions: (1) customary care (cc) and access to an intensive, interactive online education and support website intervention for 6 months, or (2) cc and monthly brief telephone calls with project staff for 6 months. We hypothesized that, at the end of the active intervention, participation in the intensive intervention would result reduced patient problematic behavior, caregiver burden, depression, and negative responses to problematic patient behaviors, as well as improved patient medication compliance. At 12 month follow-up, we hypothesized access to the online program would result in more patients remaining at home. The overriding longterm project objective was to develop an effective online education and support program for caregivers of patients with AD that can be manualized, replicated, and disseminated to other clinical and research centers, within both the VA health care system and the community, to enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of psychosocial treatment in AD.

groups.title: Caregiver Website
groups.description: relative access to website support for 6 months embedded in one year of customary care

groups.description: relative supportive telephone calls for six months embedded in one year of customary care

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Caregiver Report of Patient Medication Adherence From Baseline
outcomeMeasures.description: Adherence to prescribed medication regimen rated by caregiver on a 1 (0%) to 5 (100%) scale. Higher scores indicate better adherence. Values in statistical table below are least square estimates, and thus may be slightly out-of-range of actual respondent choices on scale.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: measure was added to study while in process

groups.title: Caregiver Website
groups.description: relative access to website support for 6 months embedded in one year of customary care

groups.title: Caregiver Phone Calls
groups.description: relative supportive telephone calls for six months embedded in one year of customary care

analyses.pValueComment: F test of time X group effect F(1,3)=.26

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Caregiver Burden From Baseline
outcomeMeasures.description: Total score on the Zarit Short Burden Scale, a 12 item instrument that utilizes a likert scale 1-5 rating of frequency. The range is 12 (never) to 60 (nearly always) wherein higher scores are more indicative of caregiver burden.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data available for analyses vary due to missing data (lost to follow-up and deaths at different points in the protocol; incomplete forms)

groups.title: Caregiver Website
groups.description: relative access to website support for 6 months embedded in one year of customary care

groups.title: Caregiver Phone Calls
groups.description: relative supportive telephone calls for six months embedded in one year of customary care

analyses.pValueComment: t test of differential change over time in the two groups t(30)=.67

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Frequency of Patient Problematic Behavioral Patterns From Baseline
outcomeMeasures.description: Total Score on the Frequency of Problematic Behaviors on the Revised Memory and Behavior Problem Checklist. The Revised Memory and Behavior Checklist is a 24 item instrument that measures the frequency of a behavior on a 0-4 likert scale wherein higher numbers indicate greater frequency. The range is 0-96.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data available for analyses vary due to missing data (lost to follow-up and deaths at different points in the protocol; incomplete forms)
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: baseline to end of treatment (6 months)

groups.description: relative supportive telephone calls for six months embedded in one year of customary care

analyses.pValueComment: t test of differential change over time in the two groups t(29)=.27

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Caregiver Negative Reactions to Problematic Behavioral Patterns From Baseline
outcomeMeasures.description: Total Score on the Negative Reactions Scale from the Revised Memory and Behavior Problem Checklist. The scale measures the caregiver's level of reaction to a series of potential problematic behaviors on a 0-4 likert scale; higher numbers indicate a greater degree of distress. The range is 0-96.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data available for analyses vary due to missing data (lost to follow-up and deaths at different points in the protocol; incomplete forms)
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: baseline to end of treatment (6 months)

groups.title: Caregiver Phone Calls
groups.description: relative supportive telephone calls for six months embedded in one year of customary care

analyses.pValueComment: t test for differential change over time in the two groups t(29)=.70

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Caregiver Depression From Baseline
outcomeMeasures.description: Total score on the Beck Depression Inventory. The Beck Depression Inventory is a 21 item likert scale instrument with a total range of 0 to 63. Higher scores are indicative of increased endorsement of depressive symptoms. Additionally, it utilizes a cutoff score of13 to indicate probable depression
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data available for analyses vary due to missing data (lost to follow-up and deaths at different points in the protocol; incomplete forms)

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of Participants Placed in Assisted Living or Nursing Homes 12 Months From Baseline
outcomeMeasures.description: Frequency count of individuals placed in assisted living or nursing homes
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Numbers vary; patients only at risk for out-of-home placement if alive and with data during follow-up periods
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: baseline to end-of-follow-up (12 months from baseline)

seriousEvents.notes: Participants were diagnosed with Alzheimer or other dementia

explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests an internet-based psychoeducation and support program delivered to caregivers (website vs. brief phone calls) for veterans with Alzheimer’s disease/ADRD — a psychosocial/behavioral intervention intended to reduce caregiver burden, depression, and patient problematic behaviors, not a pharmacologic or biologic agent. citeturn0search2

Act: Key details extracted from the trial description: randomized VA study of an intensive interactive online education/support website for caregivers (6 months) versus customary care plus monthly brief telephone calls; hypothesized outcomes are reduced patient problematic behavior and caregiver burden/depression and improved medication adherence and more patients remaining at home. This matches a non-drug, behavioral/psychoeducational intervention. citeturn0search2turn0search4

Reflect: The intervention is neither a biologic nor a small molecule nor a direct cognitive-enhancing drug nor a treatment specifically targeting neuropsychiatric symptoms with a pharmacologic agent. It is a caregiver-focused psychosocial program (educational/support), so it does not fit the four therapy categories and should be classified as 'N/A'. VA webpages describe similar web-based caregiver support programs (Web Support Project, Building Better Caregivers), corroborating the non-pharmacologic nature. citeturn0search4turn0search7

Web search results (sources used): 1) Trial record summary 'Online Caregiver Psychoeducation and Support for Alzheimer's' (lead sponsor US Department of Veterans Affairs, NCT00416078) — describes the internet-based caregiver website vs monthly phone calls and the hypothesized outcomes. citeturn0search2 2) VA Web Support Project / Dementia Caregiver Web Support — VA page describing a web support project for caregivers of veterans with dementia/Alzheimer's. citeturn0search4 3) Building Better Caregivers (VA-hosted online program) — VA online workshop/resource for caregivers of veterans with dementia/memory problems. citeturn0search7
